conclusion: Problem involves two cars with velocity-time graphs; need to determine if displacements are the same.
Graph shows car A accelerating and car B decelerating with different start and end velocities.
Velocity-time graph's area under curve represents displacement.
Need to find area under each curve to compare displacements.
Car A starts at lower velocity and ends at higher; car B starts higher and ends lower.
Visually, areas under curves seem different; need precise comparison.
Riemann sums can approximate area under curve using rectangles.
Consider average velocity to find displacement if functional forms are unknown.
Average velocity for car A is (v1 + v2)/2; for car B is (v2 + v1)/2.
If average velocities are the same, displacements are equal over same time.
Car A's curve is concave up; car B's curve is concave down.
Average velocity isn't simply arithmetic mean due to curve shapes.
Displacement is integral of velocity function over time.
Without exact functions, consider geometric shapes or definite integrals.
If areas under curves are equal, displacements are equal.
Car A starts at v1 and increases to v2; car B starts at v2 and decreases to v1.
Curves are symmetric but not necessarily equal in area.
Area under car A's curve seems larger than car B's.
